page.title: 05ECOLOGY OF GERRICK AREA
page.content: This moorland area supports meadow and rock pippets, red grouse, pheasant, wheatear, curlew and skylarks. Herring gulls and lesser black-backed gulls are also frequently seen. The heather, purple in August, offers little break to the strong, predominantly S.W. winds. Sheep keep the moorland grass short. The walker has to beware the adder. Foxes and rabbits inhabit the area, taking shelter in the bracken and heather. The area has below average rainfall but has frequent strong winds. Snow rarely falls before Christmas. Road marker posts enable snow clearance from an otherwise featureless moor. Beekeepers move their hives on to the heather in August. Red deer, from the woodlands to the north, can be seen grazing sometimes.
